page.title: 19CHEBSEY: FARMING SUMMARY
page.content: The area has a fairly even spread of farms mostly between 200 and 300 acres. Many belong to Lord Lichfield's estate but some are privately owned. Permanent pasture and crop land are in nearly equal proportions with smaller amounts of seeded grassland. Most of the farms have a strong dairy bias and the cropped land is often for fodder although there are some cash crops, especially barley. The south western corner is more cultivated than the north eastern corner which tends to have a larger amount of permanent pasture. Despite the emphasis on dairying, most farms could be classified as mixed, as they often also keep a number of sheep and breeding bulls.
